Directions




Liberally season beef with the salt and pepper. In a large sauté pan over high heat, heat   canola oil; brown meat, in two batches, about  minute a side. Remove from skillet; set aside.





Reduce heat to medium, and in the same pan, heat the remaining  canola oil. Add the onion, and cook, stirring here and there, until onion is lightly browned,  to  minutes. Add the mushrooms, and cover pan. Cook until mushrooms are just tender,  to  minutes. Add in beef broth, and simmer uncovered until liquid has thickened,  to  minutes.





Stir in mustard, and place beef back in pan. Reduce heat to medium-low, and continue cooking until everything is heated through—about  minutes. Remove pan from heat; stir in the sour cream.





Season with salt and pepper, to taste. Serve right away, garnished with chopped dill, over egg noodles  or rice.

Directions




Make the dough: In the bowl of a food processor fitted with the metal blade, place the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Pulse several times to combine. 





Add the butter; pulse several more times, then process for a few seconds to form mealy crumbs.





In a small bowl, beat together the eggs, egg yolks, and vanilla. Pour this egg mixture into the processor; pulse several times to mix it in, then process for about  seconds. Stir the mixture up from the bottom with a rubber spatula, then process again until the dough begins to clump together, about  seconds more.





Turn out onto a lightly floured surface and, with floured hands, press dough together, divide in half, form into  disks. Wrap each disk with plastic wrap; refrigerate for at least  hour or up to  days. 





Prepare the filling: In a small saucepan over low heat, melt the chocolate and butter together, stirring until perfectly smooth. Add the salt, vanilla, sugar, eggs, flour, and walnuts; stir until well blended. 





If baking all the hamantaschen at once, on two baking sheets, position the oven racks in the lower and upper thirds of the oven. If making only one sheet at a time, the rack should be in the center of the oven. Preheat oven to °F. Dab the corners of the baking sheets with butter; line them with parchment paper.





If the dough is coming straight from the refrigerator, let it warm slightly at room temperature  so it can be rolled out. On a lightly floured board, roll dough to  inch thick. With a -inch round cookie cutter, cut circles of dough, and place them on the prepared sheets.





Place about   of filling in the center of each circle. Brush perimeter of circle with egg wash. Using a dough scraper, lift dough to partially cover the filling, spacing it at one-third intervals, like a tri-cornered hat. Brush the tops of the formed cookies with egg wash.





Bake  to  minutes or until the cookies are golden brown. If baking more than one sheet at a time, rotate sheets top to bottom and front to back toward the end of the baking time to ensure even browning.





Remove from oven; let rest on baking sheets for  or  minutes. Loosen the cookies with a thin metal spatula; transfer to wire cooling racks.

Directions




Soak the beans overnight in water to cover by  inches. Alternatively, you could put the beans in a pot with the same amount of water, bring to a boil, and boil hard for  minutes; then cover, turn off the heat, and let the pot sit, covered, for  hour. I never soak beans overnight, always using the second method instead.





Drain the beans and put them in a large pot with    fresh water. Add the garlic, half of the diced pepper, and   plus   chopped cilantro. Bring to a boil. Cover partially, adjust heat so the liquid simmers quite gently, and cook until the beans are fairly tender . Stir in   salt and cook another  minutes, until the beans are very tender. Drain the beans.





Put the oil in a pot or skillet large enough to hold all the ingredients and set over medium high heat. When the oil is hot, add the onion and remaining bell pepper. Stir and fry until the onion is translucent, turning the heat down if it begins to brown. Add the remaining cilantro  and stir for a minute; then add the beans. Stir for  minutes, breaking up any clumps, and then add the rice. Stir to break up clumps of rice. Add salt and pepper to taste and continue to stir and fry until the rice and beans are heated through.
